awd_titl_txt: Convergence and Interdisciplinarity in Advancing Larger Scale Research
awd_abstract_narration:
This workshop will focus on convergence and interdisciplinarity as drivers in broadening the participation of minorities and women in mid- and large-scale research. The goals of the workshop are to 1) better understand convergence and interdisciplinarity as they relate to collaborative and inclusive larger scale research, 2) establish a network to support inclusive collaborations, 3) expose participants to strategies for identifying ?big idea? larger scale problems and establishing collaborations to solve them and 4) increase the numbers of minorities and women engaged in transformative convergent
research.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF Emerging Frontiers in Research and Innovation (EFRI) Workshop: Convergence and Interdisciplinarity in Advancing Larger Scale Research (the second in a series) was intentionally focused on convergence and interdisciplinarity in building a path toward broadened participation of minorities and women in mid- and large-scale research. The goals of the workshop were to 1) better understand convergence and interdisciplinarity as they relate to collaborative and inclusive larger scale research, 2) establish a network to support inclusive collaborations, 3) expose participants to strategies for identifying ?big idea? larger scale problems and establishing collaborations to solve them and 4) increase the numbers of minorities and women engaged in transformative convergent research.

Toward its goals, the Workshop included sessions on the influence of race and gender on interdisciplinarity and convergence research, interactive sessions involving examples of convergence research and ways to sharpen skills needed for convergent thinking and acting, sessions on applying a humanistic lens to advance convergent science and engineering, and sessions for individualized consultation with NSF program officers. The Workshop was well received by participants as they found the workshop to be informative, engaging and motivating toward convergent research. In their view, the incorporation of a range of perspectives from science and engineering to the humanities provided an excellent backdrop for understanding and exploring possibilities and opportunities for collaborative efforts involving convergent research projects and activities. The opportunity to consult directly with NSF program officers was highly valued. Evidence of the Workshop?s success includes receipt of EFRI grants by former participants as well as involvement of participants in the first Workshop as organizers and presenters in the second Workshop.

To extend the life of the Workshop, this project has been incorporated with other NSF projects led by the PI to include an online repository and community under the umbrella of the NSF-sponsored National Institute for Faculty Equity,  https://www.facultyequity.com/.
